metadata.source: Modules 5.6 (Fundamental Theorem of Calculus) and 5.7 (Net Change Theorem)
metadata.review_type: Expert human review - Beta and Copyedit passes

example.location: Question Set P5, Questions Q1 and Q2
example.issue: Q1 asks to verify a function is even. Q2 should probably use this fact. It only asks for a definite integral on [0,a] which does not rely on even/odd.
example.student_impact: Missed scaffolding opportunity—students cannot apply the even/odd insight they just developed in Q1 to Q2. This reduces learning reinforcement and makes Q1 seem disconnected from Q2, when they should build on each other.
example.recommended_fix: Rewrite Q2 to evaluate the integral on the symmetric interval [-a,a] so students can leverage the evenness property from Q1.

resolution.action: Author added a question that uses the scaffolding

example.question: Q1:MC
example.issue: To what does "property" refer? The word "property" hasn't been used in this lesson so far. Will students understand what property means in this context?
example.student_impact: Students studying alone have no reference for what "property" means in this mathematical context (is it the sum property? power property? general theorem?). Without definition, they cannot understand the explanation and may give up or develop misconceptions.
example.recommended_fix: Replace "property" with explicit language (e.g., "sum rule for integrals", "linearity property of integration") or define "property" earlier in the lesson. Term appears in multiple questions—search and adjust throughout module.

example.question: Q1:RSA
example.issue: Will students know "the sum property of integrals"? A google search doesn't net any results. Does this go by another name, like "sum rule"?
example.student_impact: This terminology may not match what students learned in previous courses. Students will be confused trying to recall "sum property" when they learned it as "sum rule" or "linearity", disrupting their problem-solving flow.
example.recommended_fix: Replace "the sum property of integrals" with more standard terminology like "sum rule for integrals" or define the term first. Note: referenced multiple times in explanation—requires multiple edits.

example.question: Q1:MC
example.quoted_text: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2 connects the definite integral of f(x) with the values of its antiderivative at the endpoints.
example.issue: Can "its" be replaced with f(x)'s in the following sentence?
example.student_impact: Pronoun "its" creates ambiguity—students may wonder if "its" refers to f(x), the definite integral, or the FTC itself. This ambiguity forces rereading and disrupts comprehension flow for students with lower reading skills.
example.recommended_fix: Replace "its" with "f(x)'s" for clarity: "...with the values of f(x)'s antiderivative at the endpoints."

example.question: Embedded Q2:MC
example.quoted_text: We need to double it because f is even.
example.issue: To what is "it" referring in the following sentence?
example.student_impact: The pronoun "it" could refer to the function, the integral, or the interval. Students must pause to decode the reference instead of focusing on the mathematical concept of even functions and integration.
example.recommended_fix: Replace "it" with explicit noun: "We need to double the integral from 0 to a because f is even" or "We need to double this value because f is even."

example.quoted_text: In this lesson, we will explore how to use the FTC together with the chain rule to find derivatives of integrals with upper a function as an upper limit.
example.issue: The end of the sentence is unclear: "...with upper a function as an upper limit."
example.student_impact: Grammatically awkward phrasing ("upper a function as an upper limit") confuses students. They must spend cognitive energy parsing the sentence structure instead of understanding the mathematical concept being introduced.
example.recommended_fix: Revise for clarity: "...to find derivatives of integrals that have a function as their upper limit" or "...with a function serving as the upper limit of integration."

example.question: QS3, Q2:SA
example.quoted_text: In the previous part, we considered the integral of the odd function f(x) = 2x over the interval [-5, 5].
example.issue: The use of "part" is confusing here, since it makes me think of the FTC Part 1 or Part 2. Can "part" be replaced with "problem" or "question"?
example.student_impact: The word "part" triggers students to think about "FTC Part 1" and "FTC Part 2" (key concepts in this module), causing momentary confusion about whether this references a theorem part or just the previous question.
example.recommended_fix: Replace "part" with "question" or "problem": "In the previous question, we considered..." This eliminates the terminology collision.

example.quoted_text: The displacement includes direction to the displacement will be less than the total distance traveled.
example.issue: Explanation is unclear. See second sentence.
example.student_impact: Ungrammatical sentence ("direction to the displacement") obscures the relationship between displacement and distance. Students with lower reading skills may misunderstand this key concept for net change problems.
example.recommended_fix: Displacement includes direction, so the displacement will be less than the total distance traveled.

example.question: Embedded Q2:SA
example.issue: Question hint and explanation both refer to the "Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1," which students do not learn until the next lesson.
example.student_impact: Students cannot use a hint that references a theorem they haven't learned yet. This creates frustration and undermines the scaffolding purpose of hints. Students may incorrectly assume they should already know FTC Part 1.
example.recommended_fix: Rewrite Hint 1 and Explanation to use concepts already covered in this lesson, or add a brief preview statement: "The next lesson will formalize this relationship as FTC Part 1."

example.question: Embedded Q1:MC
example.quoted_text: <question>How many liters of water is in the tank after 3\text{ minutes?}</question>
example.issue: Prompt is in the form of a question instead of a statement.
example.student_impact: Minor style inconsistency. Statement format is preferred for embedded questions as it better integrates with the fill-in-the-blank answer structure.
example.recommended_fix: Rewrite into statement form: After <m>3\text{ minutes,}</m> <m>\underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}</m> <m>\text{liters}</m> of water is in the tank.

example.question: P1_Q3
example.issue: The problem refers to the graph of y = 1/x, but the graph of y = -1/x is shown.
example.student_impact: Students cannot correctly answer the question because the visual contradicts the problem statement. This creates confusion about which function to analyze and undermines trust in the materials.
example.recommended_fix: Create a new graph showing y = 1/x.

example.issue: Should the chain rule be defined/redefined within the framing text?
example.student_impact: If chain rule is not fresh in students' memory, they may struggle to follow the derivation. A brief reminder could reduce cognitive load.
example.recommended_fix: Add definition if appropriate: "Recall the chain rule: if h(x) = f(g(x)), then h'(x) = f'(g(x)) · g'(x)."

example.question: Embedded Q2:MC
example.issue: Should a \ be added before the comma between the 2 and the dt?
example.student_impact: Improper LaTeX spacing may make the integral appear cramped. Minor readability issue.
example.recommended_fix: If appropriate, add \, before dt: F(x) = \int_0^x 2\,dt\text{,}

pattern.observation: Every human example explains HOW the issue hurts students
pattern.instruction: Always include explicit student impact. Don't just describe the problem—explain the educational consequence for a struggling student studying alone.

examples.example: "Creates confusion about which function to analyze" (wrong graph)
"Forces rereading and disrupts comprehension flow" (vague pronouns)

pattern.observation: Reviewers quote exact text and give precise locations
pattern.instruction: Never say "the explanation is unclear" without quoting the exact unclear text and explaining what makes it unclear.

pattern.observation: Most fixes provide exact replacement wording, not vague advice
pattern.instruction: Provide actual text the author can use, not generic suggestions like "improve clarity" or "revise wording."

severity_level.description: Minor style issues (question format, LaTeX spacing)
severity_level.student_impact: Minimal - slight inconsistency or readability issue

severity_level.description: Clarity issues (vague pronouns, grammatical errors, terminology confusion)
severity_level.student_impact: Moderate - requires rereading, disrupts flow, may confuse weaker students

severity_level.description: Pedagogical issues (undefined terms, forward references, missed scaffolding)
severity_level.student_impact: Significant - students may give up, develop misconceptions, or miss learning opportunities
High - students cannot answer correctly or will learn wrong concepts
Critical - prevents students from accessing or organizing content

critical_reminders.reminder: Always include line numbers and exact quoted text
Always explain student impact (how does this hurt the struggling student studying alone?)
Provide exact wording for fixes (not vague advice like "revise for clarity")
If confidence < 0.6, do not flag the issue
Review ONLY content/pedagogy - visual, animation, accessibility, technical issues are OUT OF SCOPE
